question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
His cellphone is / different and costlier / than mine.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: 2 (different and costlier)

Solution:
The error lies in the use of the adjective ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù. It should be followed by a preposition when used in comparisons ‚Äî typically ‚Äúfrom‚Äù, ‚Äúto‚Äù, or ‚Äúthan‚Äù depending on usage.

In formal English, the correct structure is:
‚Äúdifferent from‚Äù, not just ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù by itself.

Also, in this sentence, the structure mixes ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù (a qualitative difference) and ‚Äúcostlier‚Äù (a comparative adjective related to price) without parallel structure. To correct this properly, the sentence should be rewritten for clarity:

‚úî Correct sentence:
"His cellphone is different from and costlier than mine."

Grammar Tip:
Use ‚Äúdifferent from‚Äù when comparing two things in standard English.
Example:

  • This design is different from the original. ‚úÖ

  • This phone is different and costlier than mine. ‚ùå

  • This phone is different from and costlier than mine. ‚úÖ

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
He was enough tall / to be admitted / into the armed forces.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 10 Nov Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: 1 ‚Äì He was enough tall

Solution (Correct Option ‚Äì 1: He was enough tall):
The error lies in the incorrect placement of the word "enough". In English grammar:

  • "Enough" is placed after adjectives, not before them.

  • So, we say "tall enough", not "enough tall".

Correct sentence:
"He was tall enough to be admitted into the armed forces."

Tall enough ‚Äì ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ (‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ)

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The child was irritable / because she had not / soundly slept / the previous night.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 11 Nov Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: 2 (soundly slept)

Solution (Correct Option ‚Äì 2: soundly slept):
The error is in the phrase ‚Äúsoundly slept‚Äù. In English grammar, adverbs like "soundly" come after the verb ‚Äúsleep‚Äù, but only in specific constructions.
However, when using ‚Äúhad not‚Äù (past perfect), the verb form should be "slept soundly", not "soundly slept".

Correct sentence:
‚ÄúThe child was irritable because she had not slept soundly the previous night.‚Äù

Difficult Word Meaning:
Irritable ‚Äì Easily annoyed or angered (‡§ö‡§ø‡§°‡§º‡§ö‡§ø‡§°‡§º‡§æ)

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
It was a surprising / to receive the gift/ from my brother.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 12 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

The sentence:

It was a surprising / to receive the gift / from my brother.

contains an error in word form.

üß† Error Type:

Adjective form usage (part of speech error ‚Äì adjective vs. gerund/noun)

‚ùå What‚Äôs wrong?

"It was a surprising" ‚Äì ‚ùå Incorrect

"Surprising" is an adjective, and here we need a noun or gerund to complete the sentence after "It was".

‚úÖ Correct Usage:

"It was a surprise to receive the gift from my brother."

üîπ ‚ÄúSurprise‚Äù = noun (the correct form needed after "a")
üîπ "Surprising" = adjective (describes something, but doesn't fit with "a")

‚ö†Ô∏è Why the other parts are correct:

  • "to receive the gift" ‚Äì ‚úÖ grammatically correct infinitive phrase.

  • "from my brother" ‚Äì ‚úÖ correct prepositional phrase indicating the source.

  • "No error" ‚Äì ‚ùå Incorrect, because there's an error in the first segment.

‚úÖ Final Answer: It was a surprisingTop of Form

Bottom of Form

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I‚Äôm sure that time / changes things, but it / didn‚Äôt change anything / unlike my perception of you.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-1 (9_00 to 11_00 AM))
option_3: unlike my perception of you
solution:
The segment "unlike my perception of you" contains a grammatical error. In the corrected sentence, I replaced it with "like my perception of you" for grammatical accuracy.

The phrase "unlike my perception of you" is incorrect because the word "unlike" is typically used to indicate dissimilarity or difference between two things. However, in the context of the sentence, the intention seems to be to express that time didn't change anything similar to the speaker's perception of the person.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Bikanervala is a restaurant / chain in India / that is now famous / all ahead the world.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-2 (12_30 to 2_30 PM))
solution:
The part that contains a grammatical error is: all ahead the world.

This is the corrected version. The phrase "all over the world" is idiomatic and commonly used to convey the idea that something is known or recognized globally.

The corrected sentence reads: "Bikanervala is a restaurant chain in India that is now famous all over the world."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I do not like / your paying / for the food / every time.

(SSC Steno 2023 : 12 Oct Shift-3 4_30 PM - 6_30 PM)
solution:
Answer: b) your paying

Explanation:
The phrase ‚Äúyour paying‚Äù uses a possessive adjective (your) followed by a gerund (paying), which is grammatically correct in formal English. This structure is used when the action itself is the focus of the sentence, and the possessive form shows who is performing that action.
Example: ‚ÄúI appreciate your coming early‚Äù or ‚ÄúWe dislike his shouting in class.‚Äù

In spoken or informal English, people often say ‚Äúyou paying‚Äù, but in formal writing, ‚Äúyour paying‚Äù is considered more appropriate and correct.

Other segments are also correct:

  • ‚ÄúI do not like‚Äù ‚Äì standard sentence opening

  • ‚Äúfor the food‚Äù ‚Äì grammatically correct prepositional phrase

  • ‚Äúevery time‚Äù ‚Äì valid adverbial phrase indicating frequency

So, although it may look unusual to some, ‚Äúyour paying‚Äù is correct in this context.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
If he wants / farther information, / send him / to me.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 13 Apr S1 (9 to 10 AM))
solution:
Explanation:

‚ö†Ô∏è What's the error?

  • The error lies in the use of the word ‚Äúfarther‚Äù.

  • ‚ÄúFarther‚Äù refers to physical distance (e.g., He walked farther than I did.)

  • But in this sentence, the context is about more or additional information, not distance.

‚úÖ Correct Word:

  • The correct word is ‚Äúfurther‚Äù, which is used for:

  • Additional amount or degree (e.g., further information)

  • Figurative or abstract distances

Part of Speech Error:

  • Adjective misuse ‚Äî ‚Äúfarther‚Äù (distance) is wrongly used instead of ‚Äúfurther‚Äù (additional)

‚úîÔ∏è Corrected Sentence:

‚ÄúIf he wants further information, send him to me.‚Äù

‚úÖ Final Answer: farther information

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The woodcutter felled / some trees / with hardly / many effort at all.

(SSC CGL 2020 T-1 : 13 August Shift 2 (12 to 1 PM))
solution:
Correct Answer: many effort at all

Solution:
The phrase "many effort at all" is grammatically incorrect because "effort" is an uncountable noun, and uncountable nouns are not used with "many".
The correct word should be "much", which is used with uncountable nouns.

Correct phrase: "with hardly much effort at all"
Even better and more natural: "with hardly any effort at all"

Meanings:
effort ‚Äì physical or mental energy used to do something ‚Äì ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏
many ‚Äì used with countable nouns ‚Äì ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ (‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø)
much ‚Äì used with uncountable nouns ‚Äì ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ (‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç)
hardly ‚Äì almost not ‚Äì ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•á / ‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø‡§¶ ‡§π‡•Ä

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error and select the option which rectifies that error.
The space agency wanted / to test with a chimp / before orbiting a astronaut / in a Mercury capsule.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 13_Sept_Shift-3)
option_4: to test with an chimp
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: "to test with a chimp"

Explanation:

  • The error is using "a chimp" instead of the correct article "a chimpanzee" because "chimpanzee" starts with a vowel sound.

  • The corrected option is: "to test with a chimpanzee."

The corrected sentence should be: "The space agency wanted to test with a chimpanzee before orbiting an astronaut in a Mercury capsule."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
She has / bought / a car / two years ago.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 14_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
The segment that contains an error is bought.

The placement of "bought" in the original sentence disrupts the standard order of the verb tense. In English, past actions are typically expressed using the past simple tense, and in this case, "bought" should come before "a car."

The corrected sentence would be: "She bought a car two years ago."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
In his character, / I could hardly find something / worthy of admiration.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-1)
option_2: I could hardly find something
solution:
Answer: (b) I could hardly find something

Explanation:

  • The word ‚Äúsomething‚Äù is used for general or indefinite things, but in this sentence, it refers to a specific thing that could be admired.

  • The correct word should be ‚Äúanything‚Äù, especially after ‚Äúhardly‚Äù, which implies a negative meaning.

‚úÖ Correct phrase: ‚ÄúI could hardly find anything‚Äù

So, the corrected sentence should be:
‚ÄúIn his character, I could hardly find anything worthy of admiration.‚Äù

Hence, the error is in part (b).

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Pompeii was a tragedy / that cost the lives / of millions of people.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 17 Nov S-2)
solution:
Answer: (b) that cost the lives

Explanation:

  • The sentence refers to the tragedy of Pompeii, which historically caused the death of thousands, not millions of people.

  • So, the factual error is in ‚Äúthat cost the lives‚Äù because the number implied afterward (millions) is incorrect historically.

  • However, if we consider strictly grammatical errors, there is no grammatical mistake here.

If the question is about grammar only, then the correct answer is No error.

But since ‚Äúmillions‚Äù is factually incorrect, (b) could be marked if factual accuracy is considered.

Please confirm if you want grammar-only or factual correctness.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
It's a little lately / to go back to / where we started from.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: It's a little lately

Explanation:

  • The phrase should be "It's a little late" instead of "It's a little lately".

  • Late is an adjective (‡§¶‡•á‡§∞), whereas lately is an adverb meaning recently (‡§π‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç), which is incorrect here.

Hence, the error is in "It's a little lately".

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
He enjoys looking / a good game / of baseball on television.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-1)
solution:
Answer: He enjoys looking

Explanation:

  • The correct phrase should be "enjoys watching" rather than "enjoys looking" for viewing a game.

  • The error is in the verb choice "looking" instead of "watching."

  • The segment "a good game" itself is grammatically correct, but combined with "looking," it creates an error.

  • However, since the question asks for the segment containing error, and "looking" is part of "He enjoys looking," that is the error segment.

Upon reconsideration:

Actually, the error is in "He enjoys looking" because "looking" is not correct with "enjoys" for watching a game.

Hence, the error is in He enjoys looking segment.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
Eva‚Äôs business module / allowed people‚Äôs money / to grow steadily.

(SSC Steno 2022 : 18 Nov S-3)
solution:
Answer:Eva's business module
Explanation:
 The error lies in the use of the word "module". The correct word in this context should be "model", not "module".

  • ‚úÖ "Business model" refers to a plan or strategy for making a profit in a business.


  • ‚ùå "Business module" generally refers to a subject or unit of study or a software component, which doesn't fit this context.

Correct sentence:
"Eva‚Äôs business model allowed people‚Äôs money to grow steadily."

Correct option with error:Eva's business module ‚úÖ

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
I asked my friend / where had he / learnt to dance / so well.

(SSC CGL 2021 T-1 : 19 Apr S2 (12_30 to 1_30 PM))
solution:
Explanation:

What's the grammatical issue?

  • Error Type: Word order in indirect speech (syntax issue)

  • Part of speech affected: Verb phrase / Auxiliary verb ("had") and subject ("he")

Rule:

In indirect (reported) speech, the word order follows a statement, not a question.

  • ‚ùå "Where had he..." ‚Üí Interrogative word order

  • ‚úÖ "Where he had..." ‚Üí Statement word order

‚ùå Other Options ‚Äì No Error:

  • I asked my friend ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Correct reporting clause (Past Simple)

  • (No error in subject + verb structure)

  • learnt to dance ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Correct past participle "learnt" (British English)

  • (No error in verb form)

  • so well ‚Äì ‚úÖ

  • Correct use of adverb "well" with degree modifier "so"

  • (No error in adverbial phrase)

üü¢ So, the segment with the grammatical error is: ‚Äúwhere had he‚Äù, where the verb phrase is incorrectly ordered for reported speech.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
A celestial body or astronomical object is / a naturally occurring physical thing, association, / or configuration that happens in the visible universe.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 19 July Shift-2)
option_2: a naturally occurring physical thing, association
option_3: A celestial body or astronomical object is
option_4: or configuration that happens in the visible universe
solution:
Answer: a naturally occurring physical thing, association
Solution:

  • The error is in this segment because "thing" is informal and vague. The correct scientific term should be "entity" or "object" instead of "thing".

  • Also, the phrase "physical thing, association" is awkward without proper punctuation or conjunction. It should be "physical entity, association," or "physical object, association," to be more precise.

  • Other segments are grammatically correct.

‚úÖ Therefore, the segment containing the error is: a naturally occurring physical thing, association.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
You wash / the dishes / and / I dry the same.

(SSC CGL 2023 T-1 : 25 July Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: I dry the same
Solution:

  • The phrase ‚Äúthe same‚Äù is grammatically awkward and not standard usage when referring to objects like dishes.

  • In English, we don‚Äôt say ‚ÄúI dry the same‚Äù; we say ‚ÄúI dry them‚Äù or ‚ÄúI‚Äôll dry those‚Äù.

  • Correct sentence: ‚ÄúYou wash the dishes and I dry them.‚Äù ‚úÖ

  • Therefore, the error lies in segment 4 ‚Äì ‚ÄúI dry the same‚Äù ‚ùå

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
There is a spectrum / of seas around that / land which attracts / tourists of all aging.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-1 : 3 Oct Shift-3 (4 to 6 PM))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is: tourists of all aging.

The segment "tourists of all aging" contains a grammatical error. The correct phrase should be "tourists of all ages." The term "aging" is incorrect in this context; the correct term is "ages," which refers to the various age groups of tourists. The phrase "of all ages" is a common expression to indicate a diverse range of ages among the tourists who are attracted to the land with a spectrum of seas around it.

question:
The given sentence contains an error. Select the option that correctly rectifies the error.
Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the bad.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 4_Sept_Shift-3)
option_1: Earlier, he was feeling good, but things took a turn for the bad.
option_2: Earlier, he was feeling well, but things took a turn for the ill.
option_3: Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the ill.
option_4: Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the worst.
solution:
Answer: 4
Solution: The correct sentence is:
"Earlier, he was feeling better, but things took a turn for the worst."

The idiom "take a turn for the worst" means that the situation deteriorated or became worse.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option 1: "feeling good" is less appropriate than "feeling better" to indicate improvement.

  • Option 2: "turn for the ill" is not a standard idiom.

  • Option 3: "turn for the ill" is incorrect usage.

Hence, Option 4 is the grammatically and idiomatically correct choice.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Shelley and Keats are great writers, but I prefer the last.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 5_Sept_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: Option 2 ‚Äì the last

Solution:

The sentence is:
"Shelley and Keats are great writers, but I prefer the last."

The error lies in "the last".
When comparing two people or things, we should use "the latter", not "the last".

  • "The latter" = the second of two mentioned (‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ) ‚úÖ

  • "The last" = the final one in a list of three or more (‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ) ‚ùå

Since only two writers are mentioned (Shelley and Keats), the correct word is "the latter".

Correct sentence:

"Shelley and Keats are great writers, but I prefer the latter."

So, the error is in Option 2 ‚Äì the last, which should be "the latter".

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
He always / aimed highly / in life.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 6 Dec Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: aimed highly

Explanation:

  • The correct phrase is ‚Äúaimed high‚Äù, not ‚Äúaimed highly.‚Äù

  • Aim high means to set ambitious goals (‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ).

  • ‚ÄúHighly‚Äù is an adverb, but here ‚Äúhigh‚Äù is the correct form to use with ‚Äúaimed.‚Äù

  • The other parts of the sentence are correct.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
Existentialism has a reputation for being angst-ridden and gloomy mostly because of its emphasis on pondering the meaningless of existence.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 6_Sept_Shift-2)
option_1: on pondering the meaningless of existence
option_2: mostly because of its emphasis
option_4: for being angst-ridden and gloomy
solution:
Answer: Option 1 ‚Äì on pondering the meaningless of existence

Solution:

The phrase "the meaningless of existence" contains a grammatical error.

  • The word "meaningless" is an adjective, but the sentence requires a noun to complete the phrase properly.

  • The correct noun form is "meaninglessness" (which means lack of meaning).

Correct phrase:

‚úÖ "on pondering the meaninglessness of existence"

Why it's wrong:

  • ‚ùå "meaningless" (adjective) cannot follow "the" directly when used as a noun in this context.

So, the error lies in Option 1 ‚Äì on pondering the meaningless of existence, which should be:
"on pondering the meaninglessness of existence."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
You must / be hurry, / otherwise you will / miss the train.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 7 Dec Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: be hurry,

Explanation:
The correct phrase is ‚Äúbe in a hurry‚Äù or simply ‚Äúhurry‚Äù. The segment ‚Äúbe hurry‚Äù is ungrammatical.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
He does not / know how to / draw quickly / and straightly.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 7 Dec Shift-4)
solution:
Answer: and straightly

Explanation:

  • The adverb ‚Äústraightly‚Äù is non-idiomatic in English. We use the adjective straight even after verbs (e.g., ‚Äúdraw straight‚Äù).

  • Correct phrasing: ‚Äúdraw quickly and straight.‚Äù

  • ‚ÄúQuickly‚Äù is a valid adverb, but ‚Äústraightly‚Äù should be replaced by straight to convey the intended meaning of ‚Äúin a straight line.‚Äù

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains a grammatical error.
The article that she wrote / for the last week's Sunday Supplement / fairly criticises / the abuse of mobile phones.

(SSC CGL 2022 T-1 : 8 Dec Shift-2)
option_1: for the last week‚Äôs Sunday Supplement
option_2: The article that she wrote
option_3: the abuses of mobile phones.
solution:
Answer: fairly criticises

Explanation:

  • Placing fairly before criticises changes its meaning to ‚Äúmoderately criticises‚Äù rather than ‚Äújustly evaluates,‚Äù making the phrase non-idiomatic.

  • A clearer construction would be: ‚Äúthe article provides a fair critique of the abuse of mobile phones.‚Äù

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
They have less books than I have.

(SSC MTS 2023 : 8_Sept_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: (2) less books
Solution:
‚Ä¢ The word "less" is incorrectly used here with "books", which is a countable noun.
‚Ä¢ For countable nouns, we use "fewer" instead of "less".
‚Ä¢ "Less" is used with uncountable nouns (e.g., less water, less sugar).
‚Ä¢ The correct phrase should be "fewer books" instead of "less books".
‚Ä¢ Correct sentence: "They have fewer books than I have."
‚Ä¢ Grammar rule: Use "fewer" for countable nouns and "less" for uncountable nouns.
‚Ä¢ Hence, option (2) contains the error.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The viable of life / depends on a pair / of conflicting realities.

solution:

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The investors were / put off by the dirty / visage of the workshop.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-1)
option_4: put off by the dirty
solution:
Answer: 3 (No error)

Solution:
The sentence is: "The investors were put off by the dirty visage of the workshop."
Though "visage" primarily means a person‚Äôs face, it can also be used figuratively to mean the appearance or face of something non-human, especially in literary or descriptive language.
So in this context, using "visage of the workshop" to refer to its outward appearance is acceptable, though slightly poetic. Since the sentence is grammatically and contextually acceptable, there is no error.

Visage ‚Äì a person‚Äôs face; also, the appearance of something (‡§ö‡•á‡§π‡§∞‡§æ, ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™)
Put off ‚Äì to discourage or repel (‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø ‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ)

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
It is nothing else than / sheer foolishness that / you have decided / to resign.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-1 : 9 Nov Shift-1)
option_3: It is nothing else than
solution:
Answer: 3 (It is nothing else than)

Solution (Correct Option - 3: It is nothing else than):
The phrase ‚Äúnothing else than‚Äù is grammatically incorrect. The correct expression is ‚Äúnothing other than‚Äù when you're identifying or emphasising something specific.

  • ‚ùå It is nothing else than sheer foolishness

  • ‚úÖ It is nothing other than sheer foolishness

This is a fixed idiomatic structure. The word ‚Äúother‚Äù is used to express an exact identification.

Difficult Word Meanings:
Sheer ‚Äì complete, absolute (‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡§∞‡§π ‡§∏‡•á)
Foolishness ‚Äì lack of good sense or judgement (‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§§‡§æ)
Resign ‚Äì to leave a job or position voluntarily (‡§á‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§´‡§º‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§®‡§æ)

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Most than half of / the 14-18 year old children / in rural India can‚Äôt solve / a simple division problem.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (8 Mar))
option_4: in rural India can‚Äôt solve
solution:
The error is in the segment: "Most than half of".

  • The correct comparative phrase is "More than half of", not "Most than".

  • "Most" is a superlative used when comparing three or more things (e.g., She is the most talented of all), whereas "More" is the comparative form used when comparing two quantities (e.g., More than half).

So, the corrected sentence should be:
"More than half of the 14-18 year-old children in rural India can‚Äôt solve a simple division problem."

Correct answer: 1

question:
Identify the segment in the sentence which contains a grammatical error.
None than you deserve credit for the success of this project.

(SSC CPO 2023 T-2)
solution:
The segment with the grammatical error is:

"None than you"

Explanation:

The correct comparative structure should be:

"None other than you" or simply "No one but you"

The phrase "None than you" is grammatically incorrect and incomplete. The word "than" is used for comparisons, so a comparative form (like "better than", "more than", "other than") is needed.

Correct sentence:

"None other than you deserve credit for the success of this project."

Correct Option:

(b) None than you ‚úÖ

question:
Select the option that contains a grammatical error in the underlined portion.
I love Chennai. It is a beautiful city located in the Bay of Bengal, symbolising the unification of assimilation of culture and integrity.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
option_1: IÃ≤ Ã≤lÃ≤oÃ≤vÃ≤eÃ≤ Ã≤CÃ≤hÃ≤eÃ≤nÃ≤nÃ≤aÃ≤iÃ≤. It is a beautiful city located in the Bay of Bengal, symbolising the unification of assimilation of culture and integrity.
option_2: I love Chennai. It is a beautiful city located in the Bay of Bengal, symbolising tÃ≤hÃ≤eÃ≤ Ã≤uÃ≤nÃ≤iÃ≤fÃ≤iÃ≤cÃ≤aÃ≤tÃ≤iÃ≤oÃ≤nÃ≤ of assimilation of culture and integrity.
option_3: I love Chennai. IÃ≤tÃ≤ Ã≤iÃ≤sÃ≤ Ã≤aÃ≤ Ã≤bÃ≤eÃ≤aÃ≤uÃ≤tÃ≤iÃ≤fÃ≤uÃ≤lÃ≤ Ã≤cÃ≤iÃ≤tÃ≤yÃ≤ Ã≤lÃ≤oÃ≤cÃ≤aÃ≤tÃ≤eÃ≤dÃ≤ Ã≤iÃ≤nÃ≤ Ã≤tÃ≤hÃ≤eÃ≤ Ã≤BÃ≤aÃ≤yÃ≤ Ã≤oÃ≤fÃ≤ Ã≤BÃ≤eÃ≤nÃ≤gÃ≤aÃ≤lÃ≤, symbolising the unification of assimilation of culture and integrity.
option_4: I love Chennai. It is a beautiful city located in the Bay of Bengal, symbolising the unification oÃ≤fÃ≤ Ã≤aÃ≤sÃ≤sÃ≤iÃ≤mÃ≤iÃ≤lÃ≤aÃ≤tÃ≤iÃ≤oÃ≤nÃ≤ Ã≤oÃ≤fÃ≤ Ã≤cÃ≤uÃ≤lÃ≤tÃ≤uÃ≤rÃ≤eÃ≤ Ã≤aÃ≤nÃ≤dÃ≤ Ã≤iÃ≤nÃ≤tÃ≤eÃ≤gÃ≤rÃ≤iÃ≤tÃ≤yÃ≤.
solution:
Solution:

  • The phrase "unification of assimilation of culture and integrity" is incorrect because "unification of assimilation" is not a proper collocation.

  • The intended meaning likely involves either "unification and assimilation" or "assimilation of culture and integrity," but not "unification of assimilation."

  • Therefore, the grammatical error lies in the segment containing "unification of assimilation of culture and integrity."

  • The error is in the phrase "unification of assimilation," which is an incorrect combination.

Answer: (d) I love Chennai. It is a beautiful city located in the Bay of Bengal, symbolising the unification of assimilation of culture and integrity.

question:
Identify the error in the following sentence.
We are assured of the fact that Siben might good be the best cook to prepare chicken curry for our lunch.

(SSC CPO 2022 T-2)
solution:
Correct Answer:good

Explanation:
The phrase "might good be" is grammatically incorrect. The correct modal structure is:

  • "might be good" (if "good" is an adjective)

  • or more appropriately here, "might be the best cook"

The corrected sentence should be:
"We are assured of the fact that Siben might be the best cook to prepare chicken curry for our lunch."

So, the word "good" is incorrectly placed and unnecessary, making it the segment with the grammatical error.

question:

Nobody in the office is satisfied with your work.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Explanation:

  • "with your work" is a correct prepositional phrase.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
My flight is scheduled / to take off / on 6:30 p.m.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
solution:
Explanation:

  • The correct preposition to use with specific clock times is "at", not "on."

  • Therefore, it should be: "at 6:30 p.m.", not "on 6:30 p.m."

Correct sentence:
My flight is scheduled to take off at 6:30 p.m.

question:
The following sentence has been divided into parts. One of them may contain an error. Select the part that contains the error from the given options. If you don‚Äôt find any error, mark ‚ÄòNo error‚Äô as your answer.
The police had lot evidence / against him to take him / into their custody.

(SSC CPO 2024 T-2 (30 April))
option_2: The police had lot evidence
option_4: against him to take him
solution:
Solution:

  • The sentence:
    "The police had lot evidence / against him to take him / into their custody."

  • The error is in: "The police had lot evidence"

  • Explanation:

  • The noun "evidence" is uncountable, so it requires the determiner "a lot of" or "plenty of" ‚Äî not just "lot".

  • The correct phrase should be: "a lot of evidence".

  • Corrected part:
    "The police had a lot of evidence..."

  • Why the other parts are correct:

  • "against him to take him" ‚Äì grammatically fine in context.

  • "into their custody" ‚Äì correct phrase and preposition.

  • "No error" ‚Äì incorrect because there is indeed an error.

Corrected sentence:
"The police had a lot of evidence against him to take him into their custody."

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been underlined and given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
IÃ≤fÃ≤ Ã≤iÃ≤tÃ≤ wÃ≤iÃ≤lÃ≤lÃ≤ Ã≤rÃ≤aÃ≤iÃ≤nÃ≤ tomorrow, IÃ≤ Ã≤wÃ≤iÃ≤lÃ≤lÃ≤ stay aÃ≤tÃ≤ Ã≤hÃ≤oÃ≤mÃ≤eÃ≤.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (01-July Shift 2))
solution:
The segment that contains an error is:

will rain.

The correct form should be "rains" because when using "if" in the first part of the sentence to express a condition in the future, the verb in the "if" clause should be in the present simple tense.

So, the corrected sentence would be:
If it rains tomorrow, I will stay at home.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The teacher was (A)/ taken back by (B)/ the audacity of (C)/ the new student(D).


(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (02-July Shift 4))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is:

B: taken back by

The correct expression is "taken aback by", which means surprised or shocked.

  • "Taken back by" is incorrect because it is not a standard phrase in this context.

Therefore, the correct answer is B. The corrected sentence would be:

"The teacher was taken aback by the audacity of the new student."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
The meeting / will taking / place next / Wednesday.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 2))
solution:
The segment that contains a grammatical error is "will taking."

Explanation:

  • The correct form should be "will take". The auxiliary verb "will" should be followed by the base form of the verb, which in this case is "take." "Taking" is the present participle form, which is incorrect here.

Final Answer: will taking

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error.
I had seen / her with her mother / in the cinema hall / yesterday.

(SSC CHSL 2024 T-1 (03-July Shift 4))
solution:
The segment that contains an error is:

I had seen

The error lies in the use of "I had seen" because the sentence refers to an event that happened in the past (specifically, "yesterday"). The past perfect tense "had seen" is not necessary here. The simple past tense "saw" should be used instead.

The corrected sentence should be:

I saw her with her mother in the cinema hall yesterday.

So, the correct answer is "I had seen".

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
Sarah / will singing / at the concert / on Saturday.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.10_08-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct answer: will singing

Explanation:

  • The auxiliary verb "will" must be followed by the base form of the verb, not the -ing form.

  • The correct phrase is "will sing" (future simple tense).

  • "Will singing" is grammatically incorrect.

Correct sentence:
"Sarah will sing at the concert on Saturday."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four parts. Identify the part that contains a grammatical error.
Jack probably/ strained his back/ as the box was/ too heavier.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.12_09-Oct_Shift-1)
solution:
Correct answer: too heavier.

Explanation:

  • The phrase "too heavier" is incorrect because "heavier" is already a comparative form.

  • The correct phrase is "too heavy" (using the positive adjective after "too").

  • Other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

Correct sentence:
"Jack probably strained his back as the box was too heavy."

question:
The following sentence has been divided into four segments. Identify the segment that has a grammatical error.
He will have to / knuckle up really seriously, / if he wants to / crack the upcoming deal.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.32_21-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: knuckle up really seriously

Explanation:

  • The phrase "knuckle up really seriously" is incorrect because "knuckle up" is informal and usually used alone or with "to work hard," but "really seriously" is redundant and awkward here.

  • A better phrasing would be "knuckle down seriously" or "knuckle down" without "really seriously."

  • Other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

Corrected phrase example:
"He will have to knuckle down seriously if he wants to crack the upcoming deal."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains an error in phrasal verb.
Gita got onto / the book / she was reading / this morning.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.46_30-Oct_Shift-2)
solution:
Correct Answer: Gita got onto

Explanation:
The phrasal verb "got onto" is incorrect in this context.
To indicate starting to read or becoming interested in a book, the correct phrasal verb is "got into", not "got onto".

Corrected sentence: Gita got into the book she was reading this morning.

"Get into" ‚Äì to become involved or interested in something (‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§ú‡§º ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§æ / ‡§°‡•Ç‡§¨ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ)
"Get onto" ‚Äì usually means to board a vehicle or to start talking about a subject (‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Ø ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§§ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§® ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§ö‡§¢‡§º‡§®‡§æ)

So, "got into" is the correct usage here.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
How can someone / walk this farthest / just for / peace of mind?

(SSC MTS 2024 S.49_04-Nov_Shift-2)
solution:
Answer: a) walk this farthest

Explanation:
The phrase "walk this farthest" is grammatically incorrect.

  • When referring to a specific distance, we use "this far", not "this farthest".

  • "Farthest" is a superlative form used when comparing more than two distances (e.g., He walked the farthest among all), but it is incorrect after "this".

Correct phrase:"walk this far"

Correct sentence:
"How can someone walk this far just for peace of mind?"

question:
Identify the error in the following sentence.
The zoo is under the street from the temple.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.53_05-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: d) under

Explanation:
The preposition "under" is incorrectly used here because it means below something physically, which doesn't fit the context of location relative to the temple and street.

The correct preposition should be "beside", "near", or "across from" depending on the intended meaning.

So, the error is in "under".

question:
In the following sentence the underlined part contains as error. Alternatives to the underlined part are given as options. Select the correct alternative.
Their chance of winning is sÃ≤lÃ≤iÃ≤mÃ≤mÃ≤eÃ≤sÃ≤tÃ≤.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.59_12-Nov_Shift-3)
solution:
Answer: slim

Explanation:
The sentence should use the positive form "slim" after "is" to describe the chance.

  • Slimmest is a superlative form, which needs "the" before it and a comparative context.

  • Slimly is an adverb, incorrect here.

  • Most slim is incorrect usage; "slim" does not take "most".

  • Slimmer is comparative, not fitting here.

Correct sentence: "Their chance of winning is slim."

question:
The following sentence has been split into four segments. Identify the segment that contains a grammatical error.
They worked / very hardly / on their project / for several weeks.

solution:
Answer: very hardly

The phrase "very hardly" is incorrect.

  • The correct phrase should be "very hard" meaning with great effort (‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡§®‡§§ ‡§∏‡•á).

Other parts of the sentence are grammatically correct.

question:
Parts of the following sentence have been given as options. Select the option that contains an error.
John searched thoroughly but could not find his coat nowhere in the house.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.63_14-Nov_Shift-1)
solution:
Answer: nowhere in the house.

Explanation:
The phrase "could not find his coat nowhere" is incorrect because it uses a double negative.

  • "Could not find his coat anywhere" is the correct form.

  • Using "nowhere" with "could not" creates a double negative, which is grammatically wrong.

Other parts of the sentence are correct.

question:
The following sentence has been split into four parts. Identify the part that contains a grammatical error.
The youngest employees/ are chosen by the/ organisation to/ manage the fieldwork.

(SSC MTS 2024 S.8_07-Oct_Shift-3)
solution:
Correct answer: The youngest employees

Explanation:

The error lies in the phrase "The youngest employees."

  • The superlative adjective "youngest" is used correctly to describe the employees who are youngest in age.

  • However, in formal contexts, when referring to a group of people, it is better to say "the youngest employee(s)" if singular or "the youngest group of employees" to clarify.

  • The phrase itself is not grammatically incorrect but can be considered awkward or unclear because it might imply all employees are young rather than specifically the youngest few.

  • Additionally, sometimes the context requires a clearer subject, such as "young employees" (meaning employees who are young) instead of "youngest employees."

solution: ‚Äòafar‚Äô should be replaced with ‚Äòfor‚Äô.
